data.sense: to repeat an idea, argument, etc. many times to emphasize it, especially when it has already been mentioned or understood

examples.text: I don’t want to belabour the point, but it’s vital you understand how important this is.

data.sense: a clear example of the problem, situation, etc. that is being discussed

examples.text: Many professions feel they deserve higher pay, and nurses are a case in point.

data.sense: the more complicated or detailed aspects of something

examples.text: She seems at ease discussing the finer points of foreign policy.
He learnt the finer points of cricket during a trip to London.

data.text: if/when it comes to the point
data.sense: used when you have to decide something or say what you really think

examples.text: When it comes to the point, he always changes his mind.

data.sense: used to say what is true in a situation

examples.text: In point of fact, she is their adopted daughter.

data.sense: to continue to repeat or explain something that has already been said and understood

examples.text: I understand what you’re saying—there’s no need to labour the point.

data.text: make a point of doing something
data.sense: to be or make sure you do something because it is important or necessary

examples.text: I made a point of closing all the windows before leaving the house.

data.sense: a matter about which there may be difference of opinion or a lack of understanding

examples.text: Whether this should be enforced by law or not is a moot point.

data.sense: used to say that something is more important than something else

examples.text: I couldn't do the job—I've never been to Spain and, more to the point, I don't speak Spanish.
More to the point, did they get away?

data.text: not to put too fine a point on it
data.sense: used to emphasize something that is expressed clearly and directly, especially a criticism

examples.text: Not to put too fine a point on it, I think you are lying.

data.sense: appropriate or relevant to the situationperfect; exactly right for the occasion

examples.text: The quotation was directly on point.
Let's stay on point.
None of the replies was on point.
The music here is totally on point.

data.text: on the point of doing something
data.sense: to be close to doing something; to be going to do something very soon

examples.text: I was just on the point of calling you.
We were on the point of giving up.

data.sense: a place where you go or a person that you speak to when you are dealing with an organization

examples.text: The receptionist is the first point of contact most people have with the clinic.

data.sense: a place where a journey startsan idea, a theory or an event that is used to start a discussion, an activity, etc.

examples.text: The author takes Freud's dream theories as the point of departure for his essay.

data.sense: a thing that somebody considers to be very important for their honour or reputation
the time when you must continue with what you have decided to do, because it is not possible to get back to an earlier situation

examples.text: We have passed the point of no return.

data.sense: used to say that you accept that somebody else is right when they have disagreed with you or criticized you

examples.text: Point taken. Let's drop the subject.

data.sense: to show that you are better than somebody, especially by making clever remarks, for example in an argument

examples.text: He was always trying to score points off his teachers.

data.sense: a subject that makes you feel angry or upset when it is mentioned

examples.text: It's a sore point with Sue's parents that the children have not been baptized yet.

data.sense: to allow or do something that is not usually acceptable, especially because of a particular situation

examples.text: I was hoping they would stretch a point and let me stay on for a while.

data.sense: expressed in a simple, clear way without any extra information or feelings

examples.text: The letter was short and to the point.
His remarks were brief and to the point.

data.sense: to a degree that can be described as something

examples.text: He was rude to the point of being aggressive.

data.sense: to some extent; to some degree but not completely

examples.text: I agree with you up to a point.
